metadata.description: Academic Word List vocabulary for English learners

words.definition: To give up completely; to desert or leave behind
examples: The crew had to abandon the sinking ship immediately.
She refused to abandon her principles despite pressure from colleagues.

words.definition: Existing in thought or as an idea but not having a physical or concrete existence
examples: Love and justice are abstract concepts that cannot be measured.
The abstract nature of mathematics makes it challenging for some students.

words.definition: An institution of higher learning, or a society of scholars and artists
examples: She was accepted into the prestigious military academy.
The academy awards excellence in scientific research each year.

words.definition: The means or opportunity to approach or enter a place; the right to use something
examples: All students have access to the university library resources.
You can access your account from any device with internet connection.

words.definition: To provide lodging or sufficient space for; to adapt or adjust to
examples: The hotel can accommodate up to 500 guests for the conference.
We will accommodate your special dietary requirements.

words.definition: To go somewhere with someone as a companion; to supplement or occur with
examples: Parents must accompany children under 12 in the pool area.
Economic growth is often accompanied by increased inequality.
words.translationEn: to go with as a companion

words.definition: To gather or acquire an increasing amount of something over time
examples: Dust tends to accumulate quickly in unused rooms.
He accumulated wealth through wise investments over many years.
words.translationEn: to gather or build up over time

words.definition: Correct in all details; exact and without error
examples: The witness provided an accurate description of the suspect.
Accurate measurements are essential in scientific experiments.

words.definition: To successfully reach a desired objective or result through effort or skill
examples: She worked hard to achieve her goal of becoming a doctor.
The company achieved record profits this quarter.

words.definition: To accept or admit the existence or truth of something; to recognize
examples: The author acknowledged the contributions of her research team.
We must acknowledge the mistakes made in the past to move forward.
words.translationEn: to admit or recognize as true

words.definition: To buy or obtain something; to gain or develop a skill or quality
examples: The museum acquired several rare paintings at the auction.
Children acquire language skills naturally through exposure and practice.

words.definition: To make suitable for a new use or purpose; to adjust to new conditions
examples: Species must adapt to their environment in order to survive.
The novel was adapted into a successful film.

words.definition: Satisfactory or acceptable in quality or quantity; sufficient for a specific purpose
examples: The salary is adequate to cover basic living expenses.
We need to ensure adequate preparation before the presentation.

words.definition: Next to or adjoining something else; having a common boundary
examples: The park is adjacent to the shopping mall.
Our offices are located in adjacent buildings.

words.definition: To alter or move slightly to achieve the desired fit or result; to adapt to new conditions
examples: Please adjust the temperature if you feel too cold.
It took him several weeks to adjust to the new work environment.

words.definition: To manage and be responsible for the running of a business or system
examples: She administrates the company's human resources department.
The committee will administrate the scholarship program.
words.translationEn: to manage or run a system

words.definition: A person who is fully grown or developed; mature
examples: Children must be accompanied by an adult at all times.
He demonstrated adult responsibility in handling the crisis.

words.definition: To publicly recommend or support; a person who publicly supports a cause
examples: She advocates for better education policies in rural areas.
He is a strong advocate of environmental protection.

words.definition: To have an effect on; to make a difference to
examples: Climate change will affect agricultural production worldwide.
The medication may affect your ability to drive.

words.definition: A whole formed by combining several elements; the total
examples: The aggregate score determines which team wins the championship.
Data from multiple sources was aggregated to produce the report.

words.definition: To help or support someone or something.
examples: She aided them in their efforts.
The government has given millions of dollars in economic aid to these nations.

words.definition: Used to introduce a fact or comment that reduces the force or significance of what you have just said.
examples: The evening was very pleasant, albeit a little quiet.
He tried, albeit without any success.

words.definition: To distribute for a particular purpose.
examples: The government is allocating $10 million for health education.
We need to determine the best way to allocate our resources.

words.definition: To make different in some particular, as size, style, course, or the like; modify.
examples: This one small event altered the course of history.
We've had to alter some of our plans.

words.definition: One of two or more available possibilities.
examples: I have no alternative but to ask you to leave.
High vehicles must take an alternative route because of low clearance under the bridge.

words.definition: Open to more than one interpretation; having a double meaning.
examples: The wording of the agreement is ambiguous.
His reply to my question was somewhat ambiguous.

words.definition: To make minor changes to (a text, piece of legislation, etc.) in order to make it fairer, more accurate, or more up-to-date.
examples: The law was amended to include women.
He asked to amend his complaint.

words.definition: A comparison between two things, typically for the purpose of explanation or clarification.
examples: He drew an analogy between the brain and a vast computer.
The teacher drew an analogy between the human heart and a pump.

words.definition: To examine in detail the constitution or structure of (something, especially information) for purposes of explanation and interpretation.
examples: We need to analyze our results more clearly.
The sales department is analyzing the data.

words.definition: Occurring once every year.
examples: The company holds an annual meeting in July.
She receives an annual salary of $50,000.

words.definition: To regard as probable; expect or predict.
examples: We don't anticipate any trouble.
We had one or two difficulties that we didn't anticipate.

words.definition: Clearly visible or understood; obvious.
examples: Her unhappiness was apparent to everyone.
It was apparent from her face that she was really upset.

words.definition: Add (something) to the end of a written document.
examples: The results of the survey are appended to this chapter.
He appended a note to his letter.

words.definition: To recognize the full worth of.
examples: I appreciate your help.
I'd appreciate it if you'd turn the music down.
words.translationEn: to value or be grateful for

words.definition: Come near or nearer to (someone or something) in distance or time.
examples: The cat is approaching its prey.
Winter is approaching.

words.definition: Suitable or proper in the circumstances.
examples: This isn't the appropriate time or place.
A formal dress is more appropriate for the occasion.
words.translationEn: suitable; to take for a purpose

words.definition: Close to the actual, but not completely accurate or exact.
examples: The approximate cost was $500.
Can you give me an approximate idea of the numbers?

words.definition: Based on random choice or personal whim, rather than any reason or system.
examples: An arbitrary decision.
The choice of players for the team seemed completely arbitrary.
words.translationEn: based on personal choice, not rules

words.definition: A region or part of a town, a country, or the world.
examples: The area is famous for its cheese.
Mountainous areas of central Japan.

words.definition: A particular part or feature of something.
examples: The book aims to cover all aspects of the subject.
The exhibition will focus on various aspects of life and culture in the Middle East.

words.definition: To bring people or things together as a group.
examples: A large crowd had assembled outside the American embassy.
He is assembling a team of experts to help him.

words.definition: To evaluate or estimate the nature, ability, or quality of.
examples: The committee was assessing the relevance and quality of the proposals.
It's difficult to assess the effects of these changes.

words.definition: To allocate (a job or duty).
examples: The teacher assigned them 50 math problems for homework.
She was assigned to the embassy in India.
words.translationEn: to give a task or duty

words.definition: To help (someone), typically by doing a share of the work.
examples: A team of doctors was sent to assist in the rescue effort.
He assisted her with her shopping.

words.definition: To suppose to be the case, without proof.
examples: I assumed he was coming, so I was surprised when he didn't show up.
Let's assume that they're coming and make plans on that basis.

words.definition: To tell someone something positively or confidently to dispel any doubts they may have.
examples: She assured him that the check was in the mail.
I can assure you that you won't be disappointed.

words.definition: To fasten, join, or connect something to another thing.
examples: I attached a copy of the spreadsheet to the email.
The handle attaches to the top of the box.

words.definition: To succeed in achieving (something that one has worked for).
examples: He has attained the highest grade in his music exams.
India attained independence in 1947, after decades of struggle.

words.definition: A settled way of thinking or feeling about someone or something, typically one that is reflected in a person's behavior.
examples: I don't like your attitude.
He has a very positive attitude to his work.

words.definition: A quality or feature regarded as a characteristic or inherent part of someone or something.
examples: Patience is an essential attribute for a teacher.
He attributed his success to hard work.

words.definition: A writer of a book, article, or report.
examples: He is the author of two books on the subject.
She has authored a number of articles on the subject.

words.definition: The power or right to give orders, make decisions, and enforce obedience.
examples: He has no authority over his students.
The leader had absolute authority.

words.definition: To convert (a process or facility) to be operated by machines or computers, in order to reduce the need for human labor.
examples: The company is planning to automate its production line.
When the bank automated, many tellers lost their jobs.

words.definition: Able to be used or obtained; at someone's disposal.
examples: The book is available at the library.
Are you available next Tuesday?
words.translationEn: able to be used or obtained

words.definition: Having knowledge or perception of a situation or fact.
examples: She was well aware that he was married.
As you're aware, this is not a new problem.

words.definition: As a representative of someone.
examples: On behalf of the entire company, I would like to thank you for all your work.
She asked the doctor to speak to her parents on her behalf.

words.definition: An advantage or profit gained from something.
examples: I've had the benefit of a good education.
The new factory will benefit the local community.

words.definition: A prejudice in favor of or against one thing, person, or group compared with another, usually in a way considered to be unfair.
examples: The newspaper has a clear bias towards the government.
The article was biased against the new policy.

words.definition: A relationship between people or groups based on shared feelings, interests, or experiences.
examples: A bond of friendship had been forged between them.
The aim is to bond the group into a closely knit team.

words.definition: Of short duration; not lasting for long.
examples: It was only a brief visit.
He briefed her on the latest developments.

words.definition: The mass or size of something large.
examples: She was surprised by the sheer bulk of the box.
The bulk of the work has not been finished.

words.definition: Having the ability, fitness, or quality necessary to do or achieve a specified thing.
examples: I'm perfectly capable of doing it myself.
She's a very capable teacher.

words.definition: The maximum amount that something can contain.
examples: The stadium has a seating capacity of 50,000.
The company has the capacity to build 1,500 homes a year.

words.definition: A class or division of people or things regarded as having particular shared characteristics.
examples: The cars belong to the same category.
There are three categories of accommodation: standard, executive, and deluxe.

words.definition: To bring or come to an end.
examples: The company has decided to cease all UK operations after this year.
Whether the protests will cease remains to be seen.
words.translationEn: to stop or come to an end

words.definition: A call to take part in a contest or competition, especially a duel.
examples: He accepted the challenge.
She challenged him to a game of chess.

words.definition: A band of frequencies used in radio and television transmission.
examples: What channel is the movie on?
She channeled her anger into her writing.

words.definition: A main division of a book, typically with a number or title.
examples: Read the first chapter of the book.
That was a chapter in my life I'd rather forget.

words.definition: A sheet of information in the form of a table, graph, or diagram.
examples: The sales chart shows a clear decline in the past few months.
The doctor charted the patient's progress.

words.definition: Relating to chemistry, or the interactions of substances as studied in chemistry.
examples: A chemical reaction.
The chemical industry.

words.definition: A fact or condition connected with or relevant to an event or action.
examples: I think she coped very well under the circumstances.
Police said there were no suspicious circumstances surrounding the boy's death.

words.definition: To quote (a passage, book, or author) as evidence for or justification of an argument or statement, especially in a scholarly work.
examples: He cited the work of contemporary artists.
She was cited for bravery.
words.translationEn: to quote or mention as evidence

words.definition: Relating to ordinary citizens and their concerns, as distinct from military or ecclesiastical matters.
examples: The country is in a state of civil unrest.
They were married in a civil ceremony.

words.definition: To make (a statement or situation) less confused and more clearly comprehensible.
examples: The administration has been forced to clarify its position.
I hope this analysis will clarify the debate.

words.definition: Judged over a period of time to be of the highest quality and outstanding of its kind.
examples: Jane Austen's 'Pride and Prejudice' is a classic of English literature.
The film is a classic example of a Hitchcock thriller.

words.definition: A unit of grammatical organization next below the sentence in rank and in traditional grammar said to consist of a subject and predicate.
examples: A sentence may contain one or more clauses.
There is a clause in the contract forbidding tenants to sublet.
words.translationEn: section of a legal document or sentence

words.definition: A system of words, letters, figures, or other symbols substituted for other words, letters, etc., especially for the purposes of secrecy.
examples: The message was written in code.
He had to code the message to keep it secret.

words.definition: Logical and consistent.
examples: They have failed to develop a coherent strategy for modernizing the service.
When she calmed down, she was more coherent.

words.definition: To occur at or during the same time.
examples: The exhibition coincides with the 50th anniversary of his death.
If our schedules coincide, we'll go to Spain together.
words.translationEn: to happen at the same time

words.definition: To fall down or in; give way.
examples: The roof collapsed under the weight of snow.
He collapsed in the street and died of a heart attack.
words.translationEn: to fall down; to suddenly fail

words.definition: A person with whom one works, especially in a profession or business.
examples: A colleague of mine from the bank will be advising me.
We were friends and colleagues for more than 20 years.

words.definition: To begin; start.
examples: The meeting is scheduled to commence at noon.
He commenced his speech by welcoming the guests.

words.definition: A verbal or written remark expressing an opinion or reaction.
examples: He made a comment about the weather.
She commented on the lack of progress.

words.definition: An instruction, command, or duty given to a person or group of people.
examples: He received a commission to paint the governor's portrait.
The government set up a commission to investigate the matter.

words.definition: To carry out or perpetrate (a mistake, crime, or immoral act).
examples: He was sent to prison for a crime he didn't commit.
The company is committed to providing a high-quality service.

words.definition: A raw material or primary agricultural product that can be bought and sold, such as copper or coffee.
examples: The country's most valuable commodities include tin and diamonds.
Crude oil is the world's most important commodity.

words.definition: To share or exchange information, news, or ideas.
examples: We can now communicate instantly with people on the other side of the world.
They communicated in sign language.

words.definition: A group of people living in the same place or having a particular characteristic in common.
examples: The local community was shocked by the news.
There's a large Jewish community living in this area.

words.definition: (of two things) able to exist or occur together without conflict.
examples: This software may not be compatible with older operating systems.
Their blood types are not compatible.

words.definition: To reduce or counteract the effect of something undesirable by exerting an opposite force or effect.
examples: Nothing can compensate for the loss of a loved one.
The company will compensate employees for any travel expenses.

words.definition: To produce (something, especially a list, report, or book) by assembling information collected from other sources.
examples: We're compiling some facts and figures for a documentary on the subject.
The album was compiled from live recordings from his last tour.

words.definition: A thing that completes or brings to perfection.
examples: The scarf is a perfect complement to her outfit.
The wine complements the food perfectly.

words.definition: Consisting of many different and connected parts.
examples: A complex network of roads.
The situation is more complex than you think.

words.definition: A part or element of a larger whole, especially a part of a machine or vehicle.
examples: The factory supplies electrical components for cars.
The course has four main components: business law, finance, marketing and IT.

words.definition: A thing that is composed of two or more separate elements; a mixture.
examples: Water is a compound of hydrogen and oxygen.
The problem was compounded by a lack of communication.

words.definition: Including or dealing with all or nearly all elements or aspects of something.
examples: We offer a comprehensive range of goods and services.
The book gives a comprehensive account of the English Civil War.

words.definition: To consist of; be made up of.
examples: The committee is comprised of representatives from both the public and private sectors.
The first-aid kit comprises a wide variety of items.

words.definition: To calculate (a figure or amount).
examples: The software will compute the results of the survey.
We can compute the ship's position from the stars.

words.definition: To form or devise (a plan or idea) in the mind.
examples: The original idea for the novel was conceived in 1977.
I cannot conceive he would do such a thing.
words.translationFa: تصور کردن؛ درک کردن؛ باردار شدن
words.translationEn: to imagine or form an idea

words.definition: To focus all one's attention on a particular object or activity.
examples: I can't concentrate on my work with all that noise.
The company is concentrating its resources on developing new products.

words.definition: An abstract idea; a general notion.
examples: I don't have any concept of what you're talking about.
The concept of free speech is a cornerstone of democracy.

words.definition: To bring (something) to an end.
examples: It is too early to conclude that the election is over.
The report concluded that the school should be closed.
words.translationEn: to finish or decide based on evidence

words.definition: Existing, happening, or done at the same time.
examples: He was imprisoned for two concurrent terms of 30 months.
The two events were roughly concurrent.

words.definition: To organize and carry out.
examples: The orchestra was conducted by a young woman.
The company's code of conduct.

words.definition: To grant or bestow (a title, degree, benefit, or right).
examples: The university conferred an honorary degree on him.
An honorary doctorate was conferred on him by Columbia University.
words.translationEn: to give (a title or honor); to discuss

words.definition: To keep or restrict someone or something within certain limits of space, scope, quantity, or time.
examples: The animals were confined in a large pen.
Let's confine our discussion to the matter in question.

words.definition: To establish the truth or correctness of (something previously believed, suspected, or feared to be the case).
examples: The tests confirmed the doctors' suspicions of cancer.
Please call to confirm your hotel reservation.

words.definition: A serious disagreement or argument, typically a protracted one.
examples: The conflict between the two countries has been going on for years.
His views on the matter conflict with mine.

words.definition: To comply with rules, standards, or laws.
examples: The building does not conform to safety regulations.
He refused to conform to the traditional customs of the society.

words.definition: To give permission for something to happen.
examples: He was reluctant at first but finally consented.
She was refused refugee status, but was given leave to remain by 'exceptional leave to remain in this country with the consent of the Secretary of State'.

words.definition: Following as a result or effect.
examples: The rise in prices and the consequent fall in demand.
Our use of harmful chemicals and the consequent damage to the environment.

words.definition: Notably large in size, amount, or extent.
examples: A considerable amount of time and effort has gone into this exhibition.
The fire caused considerable damage to the church.

words.definition: To be composed or made up of.
examples: The committee consists of ten members.
The exhibition consists of a series of photographs that he took in the 1970s.
words.translationFa: تشکیل شدن از؛ متشکل بودن از

words.definition: Occurring continuously over a period of time.
examples: The constant noise from the construction site was a distraction.
He suffers from constant headaches.

words.definition: To be the parts of; to compose or form.
examples: Twelve months constitute a year.
Women constitute 70 percent of the student population at the college.

words.definition: To compel or force (someone) toward a particular course of action.
examples: He felt constrained to do as he was told.
The evidence was so compelling that he felt constrained to accept it.

words.definition: To build or erect (something, typically a building, road, or machine).
examples: The building was constructed in 1930.
They constructed a shelter out of fallen branches.

words.definition: To seek information or advice from (someone with expertise in a particular area).
examples: If the symptoms get worse, consult your doctor.
I need to consult with my colleagues on this matter.

words.definition: To eat, drink, or ingest (food or drink).
examples: The dogs consume a bag of dog food each week.
The new lights consume less electricity.

words.definition: The state or condition of physical touching.
examples: The two surfaces are in contact.
I'm trying to contact my sister.

words.definition: Living or occurring at the same time.
examples: She is a contemporary of mine.
The exhibition features contemporary art.

words.definition: The circumstances that form the setting for an event, statement, or idea, and in terms of which it can be fully understood and assessed.
examples: To really know a word, you must be able to use it in context.
You've quoted my words out of context.

words.definition: A written or spoken agreement, especially one concerning employment, sales, or tenancy, that is intended to be enforceable by law.
examples: The contract requires him to finish work by the end of the year.
The muscle expands and then contracts.

words.definition: To deny the truth of (a statement), especially by asserting the opposite.
examples: His testimony contradicted that of the preceding witness.
The facts seem to contradict this view.

words.definition: Opposite in nature, direction, or meaning.
examples: Contrary to popular belief, the island is not a desert.
The actual result is contrary to all our expectations.

words.definition: The state of being strikingly different from something else in juxtaposition or close association.
examples: The contrast between the two sisters was striking.
She contrasted the situation then with the situation now.

words.definition: To give (something, especially money) in order to help achieve or provide something.
examples: We contributed £500 to the earthquake fund.
The volunteers contributed their time towards cleaning up the city.

words.definition: A prolonged public disagreement or heated discussion.
examples: The new movie is a subject of controversy.
There was a huge controversy over the referee's decision.

words.definition: To come or bring together for a meeting or activity; to assemble.
examples: The committee will convene at 11:30 next Friday.
The Prime Minister convened a meeting of his cabinet to discuss the matter.
words.translationEn: to come together for a meeting

words.definition: To engage in conversation.
examples: She enjoyed the chance to converse with another student.
The converse of a true statement may be false.

words.definition: To change the form, character, or function of something.
examples: The sofa converts into a bed.
They converted to Catholicism.

words.definition: To cause (someone) to believe firmly in the truth of something.
examples: He convinced me that the story was true.
It's difficult to convince people of the need for change.

words.definition: To act jointly; work toward the same end.
examples: The two companies agreed to cooperate in the development of the new drug.
The witnesses all cooperated with the police.

words.definition: To bring the different elements of (a complex activity or organization) into a harmonious or efficient relationship.
examples: We need to coordinate our efforts.
The coordinates of the location are 34° N and 118° W.

words.definition: The central or most important part of something.
examples: The core of the problem is a lack of funding.
The earth's core is a molten mass of iron and nickel.

words.definition: Relating to a large company or group.
examples: The company is moving its corporate headquarters.
The hotel is used for corporate events.

words.definition: To have a close similarity; match or agree almost exactly.
examples: Your account of the accident corresponds with the driver's.
The two halves of the document correspond.

words.definition: Two individuals of the same sort considered together.
examples: A couple of people were hurt in the accident.
The cars are coupled together.

words.definition: To bring (something) into existence.
examples: The new factory is expected to create 200 jobs.
The artist created a beautiful sculpture.

words.definition: The ability of a customer to obtain goods or services before payment, based on the trust that payment will be made in the future.
examples: Her boss took credit for all her work.
The bank extended credit to the company.

words.definition: A principle or standard by which something may be judged or decided.
examples: The main criterion for the job is a knowledge of computers.
What are the criteria for selecting the winner?

words.definition: Decisive or critical, especially in the success or failure of something.
examples: Negotiating the peace treaty was a crucial moment in history.
Good communication is crucial for a successful team.

words.definition: The customs, arts, social institutions, and achievements of a particular nation, people, or group.
examples: Japanese culture is rich in history and art.
Her travels exposed her to many different cultures.
words.translationEn: way of life of a group

words.definition: A system of money in general use in a particular country.
examples: He exchanged his dollars for local currency.
The euro is the official currency of many European countries.
words.translationEn: system of money of a country

words.definition: A series of events that are regularly repeated in the same order.
examples: The water cycle is crucial for life on Earth.
The seasons cycle through spring, summer, autumn, and winter.

words.definition: Facts and statistics collected together for reference or analysis.
examples: The research team collected a vast amount of data on climate change.
This data is crucial for making informed decisions.

words.definition: A formal discussion on a particular matter in a public meeting or legislative assembly, in which opposing arguments are put forward and which usually ends with a vote.
examples: The presidential debate will be held next month.
They debated the pros and cons of the proposal.

words.definition: A period of ten years.
examples: The 1990s were a memorable decade for music.
It's been over a decade since I last saw her.

words.definition: To (typically politely) refuse an offer or invitation.
examples: The company's profits declined sharply last quarter.
She declined the job offer due to the long commute.
words.translationFa: کاهش یافتن؛ رو به زوال رفتن

words.definition: To arrive at (a fact or a conclusion) by reasoning; draw as a logical conclusion.
examples: From the footprints, the detective was able to deduce that the intruder wore size 10 shoes.
She could deduce from his tone that he was not happy with the decision.
words.translationEn: to reach a conclusion from facts

words.definition: To state or describe exactly the nature, scope, or meaning of.
examples: The dictionary defines 'justice' as 'the quality of being fair and reasonable'.
His actions define him as a true leader.

words.definition: Clearly stated or decided; not vague or doubtful.
examples: We need a definite answer by tomorrow.
There has been a definite improvement in her health.

words.definition: To clearly show the existence or truth of something by giving proof or evidence.
examples: The latest research demonstrates that the vaccine is highly effective.
Can you demonstrate how to use this new software?

words.definition: To be a sign or indication of.
examples: The red light denotes a stop.
In this diagram, 'x' denotes an unknown quantity.

words.definition: To state that one refuses to admit the truth or existence of.
examples: She denied the accusation that she had cheated.
The company was quick to deny any wrongdoing.
words.translationEn: to say something is not true

words.definition: To make (someone) feel utterly dejected or dispirited.
examples: The gloomy weather seemed to depress everyone's spirits.
The poor sales figures depressed the team.
words.translationEn: to make less active or happy

words.definition: To obtain something from (a specified source).
examples: The company derives its name from its founder.
Many English words are derived from Latin.

words.definition: A plan or drawing produced to show the look and function or workings of a building, garment, or other object before it is made.
examples: The architect will design a new city hall.
She showed me the design for her wedding dress.
words.translationEn: to plan the form of something

words.definition: Without being affected by; in spite of.
examples: Despite the heavy rain, the concert went ahead as planned.
She managed to finish the marathon despite her injury.

words.definition: To discover or identify the presence or existence of (something hidden or subtle).
examples: The security system was able to detect the intruder.
It's hard to detect sarcasm in written communication.

words.definition: To depart from an established course, pattern, or standard.
examples: The car had to deviate from its normal path due to road construction.
He tends to deviate from the topic during long meetings.
words.translationEn: to move away from a path

words.definition: A thing made or adapted for a particular purpose, especially a piece of mechanical or electronic equipment.
examples: The smart home device can control lighting and temperature.
The magician's vanishing act relied on a clever device.

words.definition: To give all or a large part of one's time or resources to (a person, activity, or cause).
examples: She devoted her life to helping the poor.
A section of the book is devoted to French cinema.

words.definition: To recognize or ascertain what makes (someone or something) different.
examples: It is important to differentiate between fact and opinion.
The company needs to differentiate its products from those of its competitors.

words.definition: A measurable extent of some kind, such as length, breadth, or depth.
examples: The dimensions of the room are 10 feet by 12 feet.
There's a new dimension to the problem now that funding has been cut.

words.definition: To make or become less, smaller, or weaker.
examples: The pain in her knee began to diminish after taking the medication.
His reputation was diminished by the scandal.

words.definition: Individually separate and distinct.
examples: The computer stores data in discrete units of information.
Each musical note is a discrete sound.

words.definition: To recognize a distinction; differentiate.
examples: It is important to discriminate between good and bad advice.

examples: The patient’s condition is now stable.
The country has enjoyed a period of stable economic growth.

words.definition: A number that represents a fact or measurement; the study of collecting and analyzing numerical data.
examples: Unemployment statistics show a slight improvement this year.
That statistic comes from a national health survey.

words.definition: The social, professional, or legal position of someone or something.
examples: Education can influence a person’s social status.
The application is still under review, so its status is pending.

words.definition: Easy to understand or do; honest and without trying to hide anything.
examples: The instructions are fairly straightforward and easy to follow.
She gave a straightforward answer to the question.

words.definition: A plan of action designed to achieve a particular long-term goal.
examples: Their marketing strategy focuses on social media.
We need a clear strategy for reducing costs.

words.definition: Strong physical or emotional pressure; to give special importance to something.
examples: High levels of stress can affect your health.
The report stresses the importance of early intervention.

words.definition: The way in which the parts of something are organized or arranged; a building or constructed object.
examples: The essay has a clear structure with an introduction, body, and conclusion.
Engineers inspected the structure after the earthquake.

words.definition: A particular way of doing something, especially a way that is typical of a person, group, or period.
examples: Her writing style is clear and engaging.
The building combines modern and traditional styles.

words.definition: To give a document, proposal, or piece of work to someone in authority; to accept someone else’s authority.
examples: Students must submit their assignments by Friday.
The company refused to submit to the new regulations without discussion.

words.definition: Having a lower rank or position; a person who has a less important position than someone else in an organization.
examples: In some cultures, subordinates rarely question their managers.
She supervises several subordinates in the department.

words.definition: Happening or coming after something else.
examples: In subsequent chapters, the author explores possible solutions.
The accident and subsequent investigation caused major delays.

words.definition: Money that a government or organization gives to reduce the cost of a product or service.
examples: Farmers receive subsidies to help stabilize food prices.
The government introduced a subsidy for public transport tickets.

words.definition: A person or thing that takes the place of another; to use one thing instead of another.
examples: Margarine can be used as a substitute for butter in this recipe.
If you are busy, you can substitute online meetings for face-to-face ones.

words.definition: Someone who takes a job or position after someone else.
examples: The company has not yet chosen a successor to the CEO.
Her successor continued many of the same policies.

words.definition: As much as is needed for a particular purpose; enough.
examples: We have sufficient evidence to support our claim.
The lighting in the room was not sufficient for reading.

words.definition: An amount of money; the result of adding two or more numbers together.
examples: They invested a large sum of money in the project.
Check that the sum of these numbers is correct.

words.definition: A short statement that gives the main information about something without giving all the details.
examples: Please write a brief summary of the article.
The introduction provides a summary of the main arguments.

words.definition: Something added to something else to make it more complete; to add extra to improve or complete something.
examples: Many people take vitamin supplements in winter.
The course is supplemented by online materials.

words.definition: An investigation of the opinions or experiences of a group of people, usually by asking questions.
examples: The survey found that most students are satisfied with the course.
Researchers surveyed 500 households across the country.

words.definition: To continue to live or exist, especially after a dangerous or difficult situation.
examples: Only a few plants survived the long drought.
The company managed to survive the economic crisis.

words.definition: To officially stop something for a period of time; to temporarily prevent someone from working, going to school, or taking part in an activity.
examples: The match was suspended because of heavy rain.
The student was suspended for breaking school rules.

words.definition: To keep something going over time; to support or maintain at a certain level.
examples: It is difficult to sustain high levels of concentration for long periods.
The forest can no longer sustain such a large animal population.

words.definition: A sign, object, or image that represents a particular idea, quality, or feeling.
examples: The dove is often used as a symbol of peace.
In the novel, the broken mirror is a symbol of the character’s inner conflict.

words.definition: A long, narrow strip of material used for sticking things together, recording sound or images, or measuring length.
examples: Use adhesive tape to seal the box before mailing it.
The interview was recorded on tape for later analysis.

words.definition: An aim, result, or person that you try to achieve or affect; to direct an action or product at a particular group.
examples: The company failed to meet its sales target this year.
The campaign specifically targets young voters in urban areas.

words.definition: A piece of work that needs to be done, especially one that is difficult or that must be completed within a certain time.
examples: Students were given the task of writing a short essay.
Managing a large team can be a challenging task.

words.definition: A group of people who work together to achieve a shared goal.
examples: Our research team includes experts from several countries.
Effective communication is essential for a successful team.

words.definition: Related to the practical skills, methods, or knowledge used in science, industry, or a particular job.
examples: The report contains a lot of technical language that may confuse non-specialists.
Applicants need strong technical skills in computer programming.

words.definition: A particular way of doing something, especially one that requires special skill.
examples: The teacher demonstrated a new technique for solving the equation.
Good breathing technique is important for professional singers.

words.definition: The practical use of scientific knowledge, especially in industry, engineering, and everyday devices.
examples: Advances in technology have changed the way we communicate.
The school invests heavily in new computer technology.

words.definition: Lasting for only a limited period of time; not permanent.
examples: She found a temporary job during the summer vacation.
The museum is closed for temporary repairs.

words.definition: Feeling nervous, worried, or unable to relax; in grammar, a form of a verb that shows the time of an action.
examples: The atmosphere in the meeting room was very tense.
In this exercise, you must use the past tense of each verb.

words.definition: To bring something to an end or to stop; to end a contract or job.
examples: The company decided to terminate the agreement early.
Train services were terminated due to the severe storm.

words.definition: The written words in a book, article, message, or document.
examples: Students were asked to analyze the main argument of the text.
I’ll send you the details in a text message.

words.definition: The main subject, idea, or message in a piece of writing, discussion, or event.
examples: Identity is a major theme in many modern novels.
The conference theme this year is climate resilience.

words.definition: An explanation of how or why something happens, based on careful study and evidence.
examples: Darwin’s theory of evolution transformed biological science.
Several theories have been proposed to explain the unexpected results.

words.definition: By that means; as a result of that action or situation.
examples: The company reduced costs, thereby increasing its profits.
She improved her study habits, thereby raising her exam scores.

words.definition: A long piece of writing on a particular subject, especially for a university degree; a main idea or claim that is argued and supported.
examples: She is writing her master’s thesis on renewable energy policy.
The thesis of the article is clearly stated in the introduction.

words.definition: A subject that you talk, write, or learn about.
examples: Climate change is a popular topic for student presentations.
The article covers a wide range of topics related to health.

words.definition: To follow the history, development, or movement of something; a small sign that something has existed or happened.
examples: Researchers traced the spread of the disease across the region.
There was no trace of pollution in the water samples.

words.definition: A belief, custom, or way of doing something that has existed for a long time among a group of people.
examples: The festival is an important local tradition.
In many cultures, it is a tradition to eat together on holidays.

words.definition: To move someone or something from one place, position, or situation to another.
examples: She asked to be transferred to another department.
The data transfer took longer than expected because of the slow network.

words.definition: To change something completely in form, appearance, or character.
examples: New technologies have transformed the way we work and communicate.
The program aims to transform students into independent learners.

words.definition: The act of moving people or goods from one place to another; the system used for such movement.
examples: Public transit in the city includes buses, trams, and a subway.
The goods were damaged while in transit.

words.definition: To send or pass something from one person or place to another, especially information, signals, or diseases.
examples: The device transmits data over long distances.
The virus can be transmitted through close physical contact.

words.definition: To take people or goods from one place to another; the system or method used for such movement.
examples: The company transports fresh fruit to markets across the country.
Public transport reduces traffic congestion in large cities.

words.definition: A general direction in which something is changing or developing over time.
examples: There is a clear trend toward online learning in higher education.
Recent trends in data show a rise in energy consumption.

words.definition: To cause something to start or happen suddenly, especially a series of events or a strong reaction.
examples: The announcement triggered a sharp rise in share prices.
Certain foods can trigger allergic reactions in some people.

words.definition: Happening at the end of a process; the best, most important, or most extreme example of something.
examples: Improving learning outcomes is the ultimate goal of the new policy.
The committee has the ultimate responsibility for budget decisions.

words.definition: To experience or be subjected to something, especially a change, process, or unpleasant situation.
examples: All new employees must undergo training before they start work.
The city is undergoing rapid economic development.

words.definition: To form the real or basic cause or foundation of something.
examples: Economic factors underlie many social problems in the region.
The theory that underlies this model is still debated.

words.definition: To agree or promise to do something; to begin to do a task or project.
examples: The organization will undertake a detailed review of the policy.
He undertook to finish the project by the end of the month.

words.definition: Always the same in form, appearance, or way of behaving across different parts or times.
examples: The company introduced a uniform policy for all its branches.
Students must wear a uniform outfit during school hours.

words.definition: To bring separate parts together to form a single unit or group.
examples: The new leader tried to unify the divided community.
A common goal can unify people from different backgrounds.

words.definition: Being the only one of its kind; unlike anything or anyone else.
examples: Each student has a unique learning style.
The painting has a unique combination of colors and shapes.

words.definition: To make practical and effective use of something.
examples: The team utilized available data to improve their marketing strategy.
Solar panels allow us to utilize energy from the sun.

words.definition: Based on truth or reason; legally or logically acceptable.
examples: You must present a valid passport to board the plane.
The study offers valid evidence to support the researcher’s claim.

words.definition: To be different in amount, size, or nature; to change within limits.
examples: The costs of housing vary greatly between cities.
Student performance can vary from term to term.

words.definition: A machine such as a car, bus, or truck used for transporting people or goods; also, a means of expressing or achieving something.
examples: Public vehicles are equipped with safety belts for all passengers.
Art can be a powerful vehicle for social change.

words.definition: A particular form of something that is slightly different from other forms of the same thing.
examples: The latest version of the software fixes several security issues.
Everyone had a different version of what happened during the meeting.

words.definition: By way of; through a place, person, or system.
examples: You can submit your application via email or regular mail.
We traveled to the island via a small fishing boat.

words.definition: To break or fail to follow a rule, law, or agreement; to disrespect someone’s rights or privacy.
examples: Companies that violate safety regulations may face heavy fines.
Publishing the photos without consent would violate her privacy.

words.definition: Existing or occurring on computers or the internet rather than in a physical place; almost, but not completely, the thing described.
examples: Many universities now offer virtual classrooms for distance learners.
The project was a virtual success despite a few minor problems.

words.definition: Able to be seen; easily noticed or understood.
examples: The stars are clearly visible on a dark night.
There has been a visible improvement in her language skills.

words.definition: The ability to see; an idea or mental image of what the future might be like.
examples: Regular check-ups are important for maintaining good vision.
The director has a clear vision for the company’s long-term growth.

words.definition: Related to seeing or to images that can be seen.
examples: The teacher used visual aids to explain the complex concept.
Good visual design can make information easier to understand.

words.definition: The amount of space that something occupies; the level of sound; one book in a series.
examples: Scientists measured the volume of water displaced by the object.
Please turn down the volume on the television.
This dictionary comes in three volumes.

words.definition: Done, given, or acting by free choice, without being forced or paid.
examples: Participation in the survey is completely voluntary.
She does voluntary work at the local hospital every weekend.

words.definition: The health, happiness, and general well-being of a person or group; financial or social support provided by the government.
examples: The government must consider the welfare of future generations.
Welfare programs aim to support families with low incomes.

words.definition: Used to compare or contrast two facts; while on the other hand.
examples: Some students prefer written exams, whereas others learn better through projects.
He enjoys city life, whereas his partner prefers the countryside.

words.definition: By which; through which something is done or happens.
examples: They signed an agreement whereby the profits would be shared equally.
The company introduced a system whereby employees can work from home.

words.definition: Existing or happening in many places or among many people.
examples: There is widespread concern about the effects of climate change.
The use of smartphones is now widespread across all age groups.
